subject: RE: [junit] Parameterisation of tests in JUnit4
msgSnippet: ... And that s exactly why it wouldn t be the only mechanism. If you wanted the values to come from a method call or a field, you d use: @Parameters
messageBody:
Cédric Beust ♔ <cbeust@...> wrote:
> On 11/29/05, David Saff <saff@...> wrote:
> > > @Test
> > > @Parameters(strings={"hello", "there"})
> > > public void test3(String input)
> > > {
> > > assertEquals(input, input.toLowerCase());
> > > }
> >
> > I like that a lot.
>
> The only problem with this approach is that you are very
> limited in the objects you can pass via annotations (only
> primitive types, and this approach won't work for methods
> that accept more than one parameter).

And that's exactly why it wouldn't be the only mechanism. If you wanted the values to come from a method call or a field, you'd use:

@Parameters (field="fieldName")
or
@Parameters (method="methodName")

This proposal makes simple parameters simple to code, and more complicated parameters more complicated to code. That appeals to me :)

Jon
